DOC.brief_summary: The objective clinical study demonstrate performance Vasculaire Compression System increase femoral venous peak velocity ( PFV ) healthy subject . This study single-arm , open label , prospective , single-center clinical study .
DOC.brief_title: Vasculaire Compression System Increases Flow Velocity Femoral Vein
DOC.detailed_description: Venous thromboembolism , e.g . deep vein thrombosis ( DVT ) pulmonary embolism , occur approximately one 1,000 person United States annually result 250,000 hospital admission annually United States . Intermittent pneumatic compression ( IPC ) , prevents stasis low limb , show safe effective method prophylaxis DVT study compare incidence DVT pulmonary embolism without IPC . IPC device decrease venous stasis augment venous blood flow low extremity . Studies suggest important indicator effectiveness IPC device prevent DVT peak femoral venous velocity augmentation compression phase compare decompression phase device . IPC device produce early 1980s 1990s cumbersome , noisy require external power source , make suitable non-ambulatory patient . Furthermore , device associate poor compliance trauma patient hospital setting , poor compliance associate high rate DVT . The aim study test hemodynamic performance new portable IPC device , Venous Health Systems ' Vasculaire Compression System . This new device design provide patient comfort convenience use provide similar improvement venous blood flow compare exist IPC device .
DOC.criteria: Male female subject 18 year old 65 year old ; Capable willing lay supine approximately one hour ; Subjects must provide write informed consent History Deep Vein Thrombosis ( DVT ) suspect DVT ; History vascular disease , e.g . coronary peripheral artery disease ; History stroke ; History pulmonary edema ; History congestive heart failure ; Diabetes mellitus ; Past present smoker ; Surgery trauma right leg within last six month ; Open ulcer wound right leg ; Pregnant breastfeeding .
